headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're very pleased with the last 3 quarters of performance by our management teams in the field. They have responded in a very effective way, as you've seen on our income statement, we've been able to maintain our productivity levels. We've been able to m
componenttext: We're very pleased with the last 3 quarters of performance by our management teams in the field. They have responded in a very effective way, as you've seen on our income statement, we've been able to maintain our productivity levels. We've been able to maintain our margin levels, if you will, with labor over those periods of time. And we're still facing some level of challenges. Obviously, we're using more contract labor than we want. However, contract labor for the company had stabilized over the last 4 quarters and, actually, on a per unit basis, in the second quarter, was below the first quarter, when you look at contract labor per adjusted patient. Our retention is a big focus and set of our company right now. We have opportunities to enhance RN retention. And we're seeing early signs of improvement in a number of hospitals that we're focused on. We had a second workshop for another 20 hospitals inside of HCA and we're optimistic that we'll start to see some leveraging of best practices and performance there that will, over time, I think help address some of these challenges. Our recruitment function inside of oneHR continues to improve and get more agile in responding to dynamics in the market. We do have pockets of challenges with wages that we have to step up and deal with. Some of those are being dealt with as we speak. Some of them have been dealt with over the past few quarters. And some of them will be dealt with in the future. Having said that, I don't think there's going to be a material change in our composite average hourly rate across the company. It could move a little bit from one quarter to the other, but largely, it's in the zone of where we anticipate it, and we believe it to be manageable.

componenttext: As we look at [indiscernible] volumes, you could see it's 5.7% for the quarter. And on a year-to-date basis, it's fallen right in line with our expectations. When I look at uncompensated care bad debt share in uninsured combined as I mentioned in my comments, look really the past 3 and even into Q3 of last year, it has remained very stable. When I look at our uncompensated care as a percentage of our adjusted revenue, it is relatively flat for the past 3 quarters. We anticipate our uninsured volume to track with our emergency room uninsured volume and indeed that's what exactly is happening. So I wouldn't really characterize the environment as very stable for us at this stage. Our teams are doing a great job as we continue to manage the collectibility and the revenue cycle associated with it. But on comp care, for the past 3 quarters has remained very stable.

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, I'll try and others can add on. Obviously, I think it's still too early to predict what will happen in '17. We've always said that we think our exchange activity will track with enrollment. And so far, we haven't really seen material erosion fr
componenttext: All right, I'll try and others can add on. Obviously, I think it's still too early to predict what will happen in '17. We've always said that we think our exchange activity will track with enrollment. And so far, we haven't really seen material erosion from payers in the markets that for next year. There's a handful of market-by-market, but they hadn't really kind of raised up as a material issue for us right now. So I really think we have to see what the enrollment trends are going to be and projected for '17 to kind of estimate whether pack it is for us. I'm not sure if you have any planned comments that we're seeing in the market on exchanges, but there's a handful of here and there are exiting and adding, so nothing material up in the stage.

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We made our early stages nothing material. I don't know exactly what the impact will be in 2017. However, we have added some payers here and there. We will lose some peers as they exit, and I'm hopeful that our network is broad enough in order for us to a
componenttext: We made our early stages nothing material. I don't know exactly what the impact will be in 2017. However, we have added some payers here and there. We will lose some peers as they exit, and I'm hopeful that our network is broad enough in order for us to absorb those, and we can maintain our market share hopefully even reposition our market share in some cases. We have to wait and see exactly how the exchange law shakes out.

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Question around the outpatient surgery volumes. Actually came in a little bit below inpatient this quarter. I think I heard it was ASP and outpatient department. But just curious maybe more specifically on the surgery centers what you guys are seeing in t
componenttext: Question around the outpatient surgery volumes. Actually came in a little bit below inpatient this quarter. I think I heard it was ASP and outpatient department. But just curious maybe more specifically on the surgery centers what you guys are seeing in terms of volumes and any initiatives or anything specific in any of your markets that's causing that change in trend?

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It actually is more on our historical trend. The first quarter was uniquely high. We couldn't put our fingers around exactly why it was as high as it was. But the second quarter was more on our historical trend, and it was very balanced between our hospit
componenttext: It actually is more on our historical trend. The first quarter was uniquely high. We couldn't put our fingers around exactly why it was as high as it was. But the second quarter was more on our historical trend, and it was very balanced between our hospital-based unit and our freestanding ambulatory surgery centers. Our growth is fairly broad-based across the different service lines in those centers and in our hospitals. We have a number of initiatives. Our OR choice initiative continues to yield value for it. It's a satisfy physician and it's helping our patient flow, patient satisfaction. Secondly, we are in an acquisition mode on ambulatory surgery centers and endoscopic centers and has added over the course of the last 12 to 18 months quite a few additional units. And when you look at our composite non same-store ambulatory surgery center growth in the second quarter, I want to say it's about 4.5%, which reflects some of the acquisitions that we've done. And we believe them to be very strategic to position alignment, greater outreach in the commercial segment and just advancing our larger network of offerings across HCA's markets. So we're very pleased with the result in the second quarter and believe we still have opportunities to grow our outpatient surgery volumes with our different initiatives.

componenttext: Yes, you're right, it implies a 5% growth to get to the midpoint. I think one of the major factors you touched on the comps get easier, especially in the third quarter. componenttext: I just wanted to talk a little more about the supplied margin. And you guys called out you start about somewhere back there, you'd talked about continued supply chain initiatives, but supply as a percentage of revenue is pretty much deteriorated declined almost every year for almost a decade now. I mean, how much more options are there that's really just continuing to push through better pricing given the GPO or the other more strategic move that could continue to drive this measure down or at least that continue to slow the growth of supply versus everything else.

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me take the first shot. So as we look at those, as you note supply cost as a percent of revenue year-over-year we have 20 basis point decline. When I look at it here for the past 4 quarters, we are pretty consistent, 16.7, 7 in Q2, 16 7 in Q1, 16 4 in
componenttext: Let me take the first shot. So as we look at those, as you note supply cost as a percent of revenue year-over-year we have 20 basis point decline. When I look at it here for the past 4 quarters, we are pretty consistent, 16.7, 7 in Q2, 16 7 in Q1, 16 4 in Q4, 16 7 in Q3, so it's very stable. And we do think that's an accomplishment given the continued intensity increases in volume growth we have seen over that time. Our supply chain team as well as our field operators have done an outstanding job from a variety of aspects around supply chain. First, relative to our GPO and contracting, we still have momentum in the marketplace with HealthTrust Purchasing Group, and they continue to have a lot of strong performance. And then our supply chain operations are really a key component of our supply chain story. We've spoken recently, one of our recent initiatives around pharmacy consolidation, where we can help control the pharmacy stand in utilization of inventory. That is paying great dividends as that initiative is rolling through the marketplace. So we've also got initiatives in the operating suites, as well as other initiatives around our performance improvement activities. So when you couple supply chain initiatives operationally with the contracting statuses we have going on, I think that's all leading to as being able to at least maintain our margins on a supply cost line and remain with stability. You do recall, last year, we did speak in the third quarter of some pharmacy cost elevation with our pharmacy cost for adjusted admission or adjusted patient day was elevated in the second and third quarter of last year mainly due to some high cost drugs that obviously have a lot of press around that. We've seen those supply cost trends moderate or the pharmacy cost trends moderate over the past couple of quarters and responds to some of just the pressure on those high cost drugs. So that is also benefiting our year-over-year kind of comparisons.

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Bill, let me add, this is Sam, let me add one comment to that. I think it's another area of opportunity for HCA and our clinical data warehouse and a number of our quality initiatives have sort of supply cost utilization, drug utilization, best practi
componenttext: And Bill, let me add, this is Sam, let me add one comment to that. I think it's another area of opportunity for HCA and our clinical data warehouse and a number of our quality initiatives have sort of supply cost utilization, drug utilization, best practice identification and so forth attached to it. And as we' engaged our physicians more than we've done in the past, they're understanding how it helps them, how it helps their facility, how it helps their patients, is another opportunity to update. I think we're in the early stages of execution on our supply cost. To marry it up with what Bill just talked about on contracting, the supply chain operational management, coupled with data and insights connected to our physicians, is a very powerful combination that we think still has headroom.

componenttext: Well, I think, on the CJR, they vary by market a bit. We are trying to work with our physicians to identify the best course of action for our patients, whether that's the type of post-acute, how we interact with them post discharge from the hospital and so forth. And it's very, very early in understanding how impactful those are. As we transition, I mean, we just got the regs on the cardiac thing, I mean, it's 700 plus pages of regs, I think, we haven't had a chance to study that yet. I think the one nuance for us was cardiology versus the orthopedic joins is we employ a large number of cardiologists across HCA and our ability to integrate with them may be a bit easier than it is in some respects with orthopedics, which we don't employ as much. So we'll have to wait and see how that plays out, that's still a proposed rule. We'll know in fact if it will go into effect and what the final rules will be on the cardiac side. But we are prepared. We've invested in infrastructure, corporate office and divisions, we've educated. We put policies and procedures in place on the CJR. It we'll hopefully see where it goes over the next 12 to 18 months.

componenttext: Yes, I'm not prepared to give pricing between the 2 units. I mean, the ASCs are a bit less priced, lower-priced in our hospitals, and that's because of some of the infrastructure requirements that it takes to operate a hospital-based unit, capital requirements are different, and so forth. Both components have about 50% to 55% of their volume being commercial patients. Our outpatient business is predominantly a commercial book of business. A number of our surgery centers have broader clinical capabilities and can provide the type of care that our hospital-based units, but others can't. They don't have the nursing, they don't have the backup, the physicians aren't comfortable operating on certain type of patients and so forth. So there's always these nuances that go into it. ambulatory centers have been in our markets for a decade and this dynamic has always existed and so we've got the right balance approach, we believe come inside of HCA to be able to respond to physician needs, patient needs, payer needs with our network, and we continue to add to both.

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll say this. Fundamentally, the company has a strategy to enhance the clinical complexion of our facilities. And by that, I mean advance into deeper capabilities. In many markets, we are adding service lines, I'll call it horizontally, where we're
componenttext: Well, I'll say this. Fundamentally, the company has a strategy to enhance the clinical complexion of our facilities. And by that, I mean advance into deeper capabilities. In many markets, we are adding service lines, I'll call it horizontally, where we're bringing on new capabilities in cardiovascular care, oncology, pediatrics, whatever. And then vertically, we are deepening those capabilities inside of existing service lines, all intended on being able to keep a patient somewhere into HCA systems if they need deeper care and more complex care. So we support that out of our clinical services group and out of our service line group up here in Nashville, where we can bring technology, we can bring best practices, we can bring a specialized talent to support that. So when I view the company's inpatient business, I anticipate it getting more acute and more complex over time. On the outpatient side, the company has had a very aggressive investment strategy over the last number of years. I think, Bill, our outpatient revenue is pushing 40% of our total. And so we balance out the $2.7 billion between inpatient capacity, outpatient, surgical capacity, imaging capacity, clinical capacity for urgent care and then also for emergency room, which is a big piece of our outpatient strategy as well. So all of those pieces and parts are connected to really a balanced approach to building out our networks and being attractive to our patients and our physicians.

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, Alan. Thank you very much, and good morning, everyone. Mark Kimbrough, our Chief Investor Relations Officer, and I would like to welcome all of you on today's call, including those of you listening to the webcast. And with me here this morning,
componenttext:
All right, Alan. Thank you very much, and good morning, everyone. Mark Kimbrough, our Chief Investor Relations Officer, and I would like to welcome all of you on today's call, including those of you listening to the webcast. And with me here this morning, Chairman and CEO, Milton Johnson; Sam Hazen, our Chief Operating Officer; and Bill Rutherford, our CFO. 
Before I turn the call over to Milton, let me remind everyone that should today's call contain any forward-looking statement, they're based on management's current expectations. Numerous risks, uncertainties and other factors may cause actual results to differ materially from those that might be expressed today. Many of these factors are listed in our press release that we issued today and in our various SEC filings. 
Several of the factors that will determine the company's future results are beyond the ability of the company to control or predict. In light of the significant uncertainties inherent in any forward-looking statements, you should not place undue reliance on these statements. The company undertakes no obligation to revise or update any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information or future events. 
On this morning's call, we may reference measures, such as adjusted EBITDA and net income attributable to HCA Holdings, Inc., excluding losses or gains on sales of facilities, losses on retirement of debt and legal claims costs, which are non-GAAP financial measures. A table providing supplemental information on adjusted EBITDA and reconciling to net income attributable to HCA Holdings, Inc. to adjusted EBITDA is included in the company's second quarter earnings release.  
As you heard, the call is being recorded and a replay will be available later today. 
With that, I'm going to turn the call over to Milton Johnson.

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, thank you, Vic, and good morning to everyone joining us on the call and webcast. I hope each of you had the opportunity to review HCA second quarter results released this morning. I'll make a few comments on the quarter and our thoughts on 2016
componenttext:
All right, thank you, Vic, and good morning to everyone joining us on the call and webcast. I hope each of you had the opportunity to review HCA second quarter results released this morning. I'll make a few comments on the quarter and our thoughts on 2016, guidance and then turn the call over to Bill and Sam to provide more detail on the quarter's results. 
Net income attributable to HCA Holdings increased 29.8% to $658 million or $1.65 per diluted share, a 39.8% increase, compared to $507 million or $1.18 in the prior year second quarter. As noted in our second quarter release, we recognized a $44 million tax benefit or $0.11 per diluted share related to the early adoption of the new accounting standard, which reduced our provision for income taxes. Adjusted EBITDA totaled $2.052 billion, an increase of 2.2% over the prior year. 
We experienced volume growth in both our admission and emergency room visits, although at a more modest growth rate as compared to recent quarters. Same facility admissions increased 0.6% while same facility equivalent admissions increased 1.6%. Same facility emergency room visits increased 4.1% over last year's second quarter. Inpatient and outpatient surgery volumes reflect solid growth over the second quarter of last year. Total surgery cases grew 1.6% on a same facility basis. Sam will provide additional comments on our volume trend in just a moment. 
Once again, we experienced strong growth in cash flows from operations totaling $1.349 billion compared to $1.057 billion itn prior year second quarter, an increase of 28%. We deployed $663 million to capital expenditures and $1.237 billion to repurchase 15.506 million shares, which included $750 million to repurchase 9.361 million shares from KKR during the quarter. We have repurchased a total of 24.427 million shares in 2016 at an average price of $76.04. We had approximately $750 million remaining on our $3 billion authorization at June 30, 2016.
And also during the quarter, we purchased 3 hospitals in the Dallas-Fort Worth and Austin, Texas markets, which we believe will broaden and strengthen our market growth into the future. We expect to see inpatient and outpatient services growth in our markets in the years ahead. We are committing capital to meet this increasing demand. For example, recently, we announced a $650 million capital commitment at our Miami-Dade, Palm Beach and St. Lucie County facilities to expand and upgrade our patient service offerings. This includes the construction of a new facility on the campus of Nova Southeastern University in Davie, Florida, along with several other expansion facility updates within the market. These investments will allow us to better serve our communities, respond to the growing demand for health care services and provide the highest level of patient care experience. 
I want to take a minute to recognize a number of senior appointments we've announced over the past quarter, all of whom have been promoted from within HCA. Due to retirements, we have named 3 new division presidents. In addition, we announced a new senior vice president of employer and payer engagement. These are all seasoned professionals with many years of experience in their discipline in HCA. They know our culture, they understand our business strategies, and I am extremely pleased that we have a deep bench to ensure strong continuity. So congratulations to all of them. 
Now moving to 2016 guidance. Primarily due to volume growth at the low end of our expectations during the first 6 months of 2016, we are revising our full year 2016 guidance expectations. As noted in this morning's earnings release, our revenue range is now estimated to be between $41 and $42 billion, adjusted EBITDA is now expected to range between $8.1 billion and $8.3 billion and our adjusted EPS range is now estimated between $6.40 to $6.70 per diluted share, reflecting increased net income, share repurchase and the favorable impact of change in accounting standard, which lowered our tax rate for the first 6 months of 2016. Our balance for capital expenditures for 2016 remains around $2.7 billion. 
So with that, I'll turn the call over to Bill.

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Good morning, everyone. And I will add to Milton's comments and provide more detail on our performance and our health reform trends in the quarter. As we reported, in the second quarter, our same facility admissions increased 0.6% over prior year a
componenttext:
Great. Good morning, everyone. And I will add to Milton's comments and provide more detail on our performance and our health reform trends in the quarter. As we reported, in the second quarter, our same facility admissions increased 0.6% over prior year and equivalent admissions increased 1.6%. 
Sam will provide more commentary on volume in a moment, but I'll give you some trends by payer class. During the second quarter, same facility Medicare admissions and equivalent admissions increased 1.2% and 2.1%, respectively. This includes both traditional and managed Medicare. Managed Medicare admissions increased 3.9% on a same facility basis and now represent 33.5% of our total Medicare admissions. Same facility Medicaid admissions and equivalent admissions increased 0.5% and 2.1%, respectively, in the quarter, which is fairly consistent with our recent trends. 
Same facility self-pay and charity admissions increased 5.7% in the quarter, and they represent 7.5% of total admissions compared to 7.1% in the second quarter of last year. Year-to-date, our same facility uninsured admissions are up 7.8% from the same period last year. 
Managed care and other, which include exchange, admissions declined 1.6%, and equivalent admissions declined 0.8% on the same facility basis in the second quarter compared with the prior year. On a year-to-date basis, same facility managed, other and exchange admissions are flat with prior year, and equivalent admissions are up 0.9%. Same facility emergency room business increased 4.1% in the quarter compared to the prior year, and our same facility self-pay and charity ER visits represent 19.4% of our total ER visits in the quarter compared to 19.3% last year. 
Intensity of services, or acuity, increased in the quarter with our same facility case mix increasing 3.9% compared to the prior year period. Same facility surgeries increased 1.6% in the quarter, the same facility inpatient surgeries increased 1.8% and outpatient surgeries increasing 1.5% in the prior year. Same facility revenue for equivalent admission increased 2.1%. 
Same facility managed care and other, including exchange revenue per equivalent admission, increased 5.8% in the quarter. Same facility charity care and uninsured discounts increased $863 million in the quarter compared to the prior year. Same facility charity care discounts totaled $1.097 billion in the quarter, an increase of $207 million from the prior year period, while same facility uninsured discounts totaled $3.085 billion, an increase of $656 million over the prior year period. Our total uncompensated care trends, which include bad debts, charity and uninsured business, combined, have been consistent over the past 4 quarters. 
Now turning to expenses. Expense management in the quarter was good. Same facility operating expense per equivalent admission increased 2.4% compared to last year's second quarter. Our consolidated adjusted EBITDA margin, adjusted per share-based comp and EHR incentive income, is 20.5% for the quarter compared to 20.7% in the second quarter of last year. Sequentially, it has increased 40 basis points from the first quarter of this year. 
Same facility salaries per equivalent admission increased 2.4% compared to last year's second quarter. Salaries and benefits as a percentage of revenue increased 10 basis points compared to the second quarter of 2015. 
Same facility supply expense per equivalent admission increased 0.9% for the second quarter compared to the prior year period, reflecting growth in surgical volumes. And the impact of this volume growth is offset by several supply chain initiative that we have implemented, and this helped leads the supply cost revenue to improve 20 basis points versus the prior year period. 
Other operating expenses as a percent of revenues increased 30 basis points from last year's second quarter to 18.0% of revenues, primarily reflecting an increase in our year-over-year professional fee that we discussed on our first quarter call. However, other operating expenses as a percentage of revenue has remained level through the past 4 quarters. We recognized $5 million electronic health record income in the quarter compared to $18 million in last year's second quarter, consistent with our expectations. 
Let me touch briefly on cash flows. We had another strong quarter with cash flows from operations totaling $1.349 billion. Year-to-date, cash flows from operations, $2.748 billion or a 32.4% increase from prior year. Cash flow from operations is benefited by $118 million on a year-to-date basis due to the adoption of the accounting policy around excess tax benefits related to the settlement of equity awards. 
At the end of the quarter, we had approximately $1.98 billion available under our revolving credit facilities. Debt to adjusted EBITDA was 3.93x at June 30, 2016, compared with 3.85x at December 31, '15. 
I also want to highlight our earnings per share results. For the quarter, our diluted earnings per share before considering losses on retirement of debt, legal claim costs and gain on losses of sales of facilities increased to $1.66 per diluted share from $1.37 in the prior year period. When adjusted for the $0.11 benefit due to the adopting of the new accounting policy, represents a 13% growth over prior year in the quarter. These strong cash flow trends, balance sheet position and EPS growth results highlight an important strength of the company. 
Let me touch briefly on health care reform. Health reform activity continued to grow in the quarter. In the second quarter, we saw approximately 13,300 same facility exchange admissions as compared with the 11,600 we saw in the second quarter of last year or a 15% year-over-year growth. You may recall, we saw about 12,500 exchange admissions in the first quarter. We saw approximately 54,000 same facility exchange ER visits in the second quarter compared to just under 45,000 in the second quarter of 2015 and just under 50,000 in the first quarter of 2016. So overall, these reform trends are tracking in line with our expectations. 
So that concludes my remarks, and I'll turn the call over to Sam for some additional comments.

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Let me begin by giving you some of the quarterly volumes that I normally provide on each call. Once again, the company continued to have broad-based growth across our markets and broad-based growth across various service lines that make up o
componenttext:
Good morning. Let me begin by giving you some of the quarterly volumes that I normally provide on each call. Once again, the company continued to have broad-based growth across our markets and broad-based growth across various service lines that make up our business. 
For our domestic operation, on a same facility basis, 10 of 14 divisions had growth in admissions, 11 of 14 divisions had growth in adjusted admissions and 12 of 14 divisions had growth in emergency room visits. Freestanding emergency room visits grew 27% and accounted for approximately 50% of our overall ER growth. Hospital-based emergency room visits grew 2.2%. 
In addition to the strong portfolio performance, the company's growth across its diversified service lines was also strong. For domestic operations, on a same facility basis, inpatient surgeries grew 1.7%, which increased surgical admissions to 28.6% of total in the quarter, an increase of 130 basis points. Surgical volumes were particularly strong in cardiovascular, orthopedics and general surgery categories. Outpatient surgeries grew by 1.4%. Both components of this service line, hospital-based and our freestanding ambulatory division, had solid growth. Also, same facility outpatient endoscopic procedures grew 1.6%. 
Behavioral health admissions grew 3.7%. Rehab admissions grew 1.2%. Cardiology procedure volumes grew approximately 2%. Trauma volumes grew 14%. Observation visits were up 7.5%, and finally, the company's urgent care visit on a non-same facility basis grew 11%. Two related service lines experienced declines in the quarter. Deliveries were down 1.5% in the quarter, and neonatal admissions declined 2.6%. Overall, average length of stay increased 0.6%. This was driven mainly by the growth in our acuity or case mix index. We believe our efforts in developing a more comprehensive and complex level of services across our provider networks are driving this increase. 
I would also note that our inpatient market share for the year ended 2015 showed that HCA continued to gain share in total and across most of its market. As stated earlier, our volume growth, in particular, inpatient admission, was at the lower end of our expectations. Most of this can be attributed to 3 areas. But before I explain them, it is important to note that the second quarter last year was very strong and presented a difficult comparison with inpatient admissions up 4.1% and adjusted admissions up 4.9%. 
First, growth in emergency room visits in our hospital-based units slowed as compared to the past few years. As a result, downstream growth in inpatient admission through the ER was not as strong as compared to recent quarters. We believe most of this softness can be explained by 3 factors: first, a slowing in demand growth to more normal rates; second, new competition in several markets; and third, in a couple of our Florida markets, we experienced a change in how certain Medicare Advantage payer classified their patients between inpatient admission and observation status. The company continues to execute a comprehensive agenda to grow our emergency room business, which we believe is a service line with strong overall demand growth. 
Second, growth in our behavioral and rehab service lines was also recent trends [ph]. We believe this issue is mostly a result of capacity constraint caused by clinical staffing and a lack of bed at a few of our behavioral units. On the rehab side of our business, the issues are not as easily categorized. We have not opened as many units this year as compared to past year, and we have seen some modest impact in a few markets from the CMS bundled payment initiative. We continue to invest in and recruit talents for these service lines, and we believe they have solid growth prospects in many of our markets. 
And finally, women's and children submissions were down as I indicated previously. The primary reasons are, one, broad-based softness in delivery [indiscernible] downstream decline in neonatal admissions, some competitive issues in a few markets and general declines in pediatric volume due to a milder respiratory season as compared to last year. These services continue to be an important part of our overall network strategy, and we believe the company is well positioned to compete effectively in these areas. 
All in all, the company continues to have solid top line growth and sustain market share gains. Our growth agenda is comprehensive. It is well resourced for capital spending and marketing, and we continue to execute at a high level. We believe the company has solid growth prospects across a uniquely diversified portfolio of markets and service lines, and we believe our local provider system are well positioned to capitalize on them. 
With that, let me turn the call back to Vic.

componenttextpreview: Yes. As we look at cash flow from operations, obviously, it's been very strong year to date. We're encouraged. We anticipate that strength to continue. We have previously said that cash flow from operations will be about $5.5 billion to $5.5 billion, I th
componenttext: Yes. As we look at cash flow from operations, obviously, it's been very strong year to date. We're encouraged. We anticipate that strength to continue. We have previously said that cash flow from operations will be about $5.5 billion to $5.5 billion, I think we're still within that range, and free cash flow will be in around that $2 billion to $2.2 billion is still what we anticipate at this stage of the year.

componenttext: Great, so no change to that.

componenttext: No. Whit, let me just add one more. Other than the impact of the accounting change that we talked about, we haven't projected for that for the balance of the year.

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we'll go to Sheryl Skolnick with Mizuho.
componenttext: Next, we'll go to Sheryl Skolnick with Mizuho.

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We all knew it was going to be tough to go up against the great job you did last year on volumes, but I'd like to delve into that, because as volumes go, so goes everything else. If I could just recap and then ask the question. First, I think what we're s
componenttext: We all knew it was going to be tough to go up against the great job you did last year on volumes, but I'd like to delve into that, because as volumes go, so goes everything else. If I could just recap and then ask the question. First, I think what we're seeing here is still growth across the broad range of types of admissions and payer types, but softer than you had expected. I think I heard you say managed care admissions were down. So I'd like some explanation of that, where it happens and whether or not it's likely to be sustained. Third, we heard you, on the other side of this, talk about the capacity constraint, and I'm wondering to what extent your capacity constraint is limiting your near-term growth and what your plans are for investing to -- beyond Florida, what you've announced, to offset that. And then fourth, you have this fact that you are investing in capacity. So there's a bit of a mixed message here, the way I'm seeing it, that, yes, on the one hand, you're pulling in guidance prudently to reflect a little bit less strength, but still growth. On the other hand, I hear what you're saying about investing at capacity. So it sounds that there might be a demand story here and a continued execution story. Bill, can you tell us what we should think about the near-term pushes and pulls versus the long-term growth expectations you have for volumes and how we should think about the company in that context?

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sheryl, thank you. That's a great question. Milt, you want to lead then Sam?
componenttext: Sheryl, thank you. That's a great question. Milt, you want to lead then Sam?

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me just lead in that, and Sam, I know, can get some additional color, details on this. But first of all, Sheryl, I think you're right. What we're seeing is we were still seeing growth in longer-term historical standards, I think very solid growth
componenttext: Yes. Let me just lead in that, and Sam, I know, can get some additional color, details on this. But first of all, Sheryl, I think you're right. What we're seeing is we were still seeing growth in longer-term historical standards, I think very solid growth, and that's -- hopefully, we're expressing that this morning. But by recent growth standards, we're seeing it slowing. We went through, over the past 5 or 6 quarters, growth that was exceptional, and we saw demand in our markets growing. And we suspect -- although, as you know, our market share data lags about 6 months, but we suspect we're going to see some slowing demand in many of our markets, and that's why we're seeing it show up in our numbers. That being said, we still have a great outlook and a very optimistic outlook for the long term in our markets. Our markets are growing in terms of population, and I think we'll continue to see demand in our markets. And so we're going to invest to meet that expected demand. And we have certain markets, I know Sam can give some color like on the South Florida markets, where we announced the $650 million investment, why we're doing that. And Sam can describe that to you just -- in just a minute. But we still think our markets -- we're well positioned in our markets, and we're going to invest to make sure we stay well positioned in these excellent markets in which we operate. So Sam, do you want to add a little more color to that?

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think, though, in the second quarter, capacity constraint played a broad-based role in the softening. There are pockets where we clearly know that it's difficult day in and day out to manage the capacity challenges, and that could, in fact, squeez
componenttext: I don't think, though, in the second quarter, capacity constraint played a broad-based role in the softening. There are pockets where we clearly know that it's difficult day in and day out to manage the capacity challenges, and that could, in fact, squeeze out a few patients here or there. But in total, I don't think that was a material impact in the quarter. We have a very sophisticated approach to capital expenditures. We have capacity triggers. We have production triggers that we use in determining whether or not we should consider capital for a particular situation. And so that process continues. Nothing's changed. And we monitor that in the context of macros within the market, of strategic approach within the facility at micro level, and all of that leads into a capital decision. Capital takes a while to get into the marketplace. On average, it's 18 to 30 months, depending on the project, because we're usually doing it to existing assets. So that timing gives us a bit of a hedge, also, I think, in deploying capital across the company. But it's -- specifically, you get the example of East Florida and what we've done there. And a number of these projects that were -- have been approved, we packaged them up because we thought it was a very sizable commitment and a very effective message for constituents in that market. But -- the South Florida market is the largest health care demand market in HCA. Dallas is second. Houston is third. So Miami is a big market. We have the largest position in Miami with our market share globally. Our volumes, over the past 5 years, have grown significantly. Our census, our average daily census is up 25%. We have a number of our key institutions that are running 85% to 90% inpatient occupancy. Our emergency room visits over that time period have grown almost 250,000 visits or almost 50%. It's a large commercial market. So for us -- and when you look at the macros in South Florida, we believe we have to get capacity in play in order to sustain growth over time, and that's how we think about these investments. And this is just a very solid sort of microcosm, if you will, of a number of markets in a number of situations inside of HCA and how we approach it. So capital is a very important part of market share gains. It's very important part of constituency satisfaction, especially our position, and then obviously our patients in that they have the kind of facility presentation and technology they needed. And it continues to play a big part in our overall efforts to grow market share and position our company to be effective in delivering care and competitive in the marketplace.

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, if I could just refine this, please, to answer the other part of the questions. How should we think about the near-term volume outlook for the company versus the longer term volume outlook? And can you just go through the managed care and what happe
componenttext: Well, if I could just refine this, please, to answer the other part of the questions. How should we think about the near-term volume outlook for the company versus the longer term volume outlook? And can you just go through the managed care and what happened there?

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think our managed care, we were flattish. So let's just say it's modestly down. That's a little bit below where we expect it this year. I mean, the last 6 quarters have been incredibly strong, from a commercial demand standpoint, across all of our
componenttext: Well, I think our managed care, we were flattish. So let's just say it's modestly down. That's a little bit below where we expect it this year. I mean, the last 6 quarters have been incredibly strong, from a commercial demand standpoint, across all of our markets and then commercial volume inside of HCA. We knew that was going to taper. We just didn't know when exactly and how much. And I don't know that the second quarter is necessarily reflective of any near-term volume trend with respect to that. I mean, the second quarter last year was a very strong commercial volume growth, if I remember correctly, Bill, and so that was part of the challenge here. We have a couple of markets where there's been some trend changes. The observation issue in the Florida market impacted our admission statistics a bit and that's part of it. A couple of Texas markets have softened some, but not materially different than the company as a whole. In Las Vegas, 2 of our hospitals I mean, 2 of our competitors have now reentered a payer contract that previously they weren't in, so we lost a bit of commercial business there. So there's all these little components that play into our number. But I think the demand will normalize, and that trend, we think, in the short run to intermediate run on commercial ought to be somewhere between 1 and 2. We think overall demand is 2 to 2.5, potentially. But again, we're going to have to see some data in the first part of this year to fully validate those assumptions, but that's where we believe the trends are for the HCA markets.

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sheryl, one thing I might just add, and that is, as we all know, the health exchange admissions really grew last year. And again, they're a small piece of the company. But if you look at what they added to admission growth last year in the second quarter
componenttext: Sheryl, one thing I might just add, and that is, as we all know, the health exchange admissions really grew last year. And again, they're a small piece of the company. But if you look at what they added to admission growth last year in the second quarter versus this year while they're still growing, it's about 100 basis points linked. So that's also one factor to keep in mind when we start comping the last year. Milton, you have something to add?

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have something to point out. Absorbed, I think, Bill, 2.4% of -- year-to-date on our adjusted admission growth. You recall, we gave guidance of 2.5% to 4%. So we're at the low end of that range. And so when you think about the short term, the next 6 mon
componenttext: I have something to point out. Absorbed, I think, Bill, 2.4% of -- year-to-date on our adjusted admission growth. You recall, we gave guidance of 2.5% to 4%. So we're at the low end of that range. And so when you think about the short term, the next 6 months, we think we can finish within the range, but it will probably be in the lower end of our range when things shut [ph] for the year.

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we'll go to A.J. Rice with UBS.
componenttext: Next, we'll go to A.J. Rice with UBS.

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I might switch gears and ask you about for some -- update on the payers side. I wonder -- you mentioned about some pressure from managed care and Florida on pushing to observation stage, which we've heard from some of the others. Can you broadly comment o
componenttext: I might switch gears and ask you about for some -- update on the payers side. I wonder -- you mentioned about some pressure from managed care and Florida on pushing to observation stage, which we've heard from some of the others. Can you broadly comment on where you're at in contracting future business with managed care guys? Has that changed in terms of the contracts you've seen? Or does that relate more to just them being aggressive on utilization review? And then you mentioned, Sam, I think in your comments about bundled payments and what you're seeing there. Can you comment on the government's initiatives around CJR and what you've learned at and whether that -- a little more on the impact that's having.

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. We are about 75% contracted for 2017. Again, that's consistent recent past year terms. We're about 50% contracted on '18 similarly. As far as the components of that, we are -- I'm not seeing any substantial changes in structure or provisions inside
componenttext: Okay. We are about 75% contracted for 2017. Again, that's consistent recent past year terms. We're about 50% contracted on '18 similarly. As far as the components of that, we are -- I'm not seeing any substantial changes in structure or provisions inside of those agreements. On the observation status issue, it was more Medicare Advantage issue than it was a non-Medicare issue, a little bit on the commercial, but not as much. It was more Medicare Advantage, but a little bit on the commercial because of that. We're not convinced yet that we're being equitably dealt with on some of those status, and you're working with the payers to get a more clinically driven protocol around those. And that, we believe, will normalize at some point. But nonetheless, that's out there as an issue, and it has been an issue, but it was a little more advance, I think, in the second quarter. So that's the payer side. On the bundled payment issue, again, it's hard to have current data. This is a very sort of slow-moving data-driven process with the government. What I was speaking to was, in particular, on our rehab business, and only in a couple of markets have we seen the BPCI program, the bundled payment initiative pilot program, have a modest impact on referrals into our rehab centers. There have been some components of our participation in those pilots where we're seeing some modest adjustments in post-acute care referral patterns. Again, it's sort of spotty across the different components of post-acute. On the CJR side, it's way too early to be able to understand what the implications are there. We're just starting to get in the game. And again, we've seen some modest changes in referral patterns, but not to the point where, for HCA, we believe that compromises the opportunity to develop rehab service lines and fully integrate that into other components of our business. So orthopedics, as an example, is not the only driver of rehab business for HCA. Trauma is a driver. Real sciences are a driver. Outreach into the rural market is a driver. So we have multiple drivers that deliver downstream rehab have business. And so from that standpoint, you got a little bit of a drag with the bundled programs. We still have a lot of business opportunity on the other side that justifies our investments. Rehab admissions for HCA are 1% of our total, so it doesn't really move the needle at all.

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we'll go to Chris Rigg with Susquehanna Financial Group.
componenttext: Next, we'll go to Chris Rigg with Susquehanna Financial Group.

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask about labor. It doesn't seem like you guys are having any issues. But given some of the issues that have been discussed by your peers, would love to just get a sense for what you're seeing in the market and just overall labor [indisce
componenttext: I just wanted to ask about labor. It doesn't seem like you guys are having any issues. But given some of the issues that have been discussed by your peers, would love to just get a sense for what you're seeing in the market and just overall labor [indiscernible].

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Chris, thank you. Sam, do you want to?
componenttext: All right. Chris, thank you. Sam, do you want to?

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're very pleased with the last 3 quarters of performance by our management teams in the field. They have responded in a very effective way. As you've seen on our income statement, we've been able to maintain our productivity levels. We've been able to m
componenttext: We're very pleased with the last 3 quarters of performance by our management teams in the field. They have responded in a very effective way. As you've seen on our income statement, we've been able to maintain our productivity levels. We've been able to maintain our margin levels, if you will, with labor over those periods of time. And we're still facing some level of challenges. Obviously, we're using more contract labor than we want. However, contract labor for the company had stabilized over the last 4 quarters and, actually, on a per unit basis, in the second quarter, was below the first quarter when we look at contract labor per adjusted patient day. RN retention is a big focus inside of our company right now. We have opportunities to enhance RN retention, and we're seeing early signs of improvement at a number of hospitals that we're focused on. We had a second workshop with other 20 hospitals inside of HCA, and we're optimistic that we'll start to see some leveraging of best practices and performance there that will, over time, I think, help address some of these challenges. Our recruitment function inside of oneHR continues to improve and get more agile in responding to dynamics in the market. We do have pockets of challenges with wages that we have to step up and deal with. Some of those are being dealt with as we speak, some of them have been dealt with over the past few quarters and some of them will be dealt with in the future. Having said that, I don't think there is going to be a material change in our composite average hourly rate across the company. It could move a little bit from one quarter to the other. But largely, it's in the zone of where we anticipate it, and we believe it to be manageable.

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: A lot of good color around the top line issues, and obviously, you mentioned labor. I'm just curious on the bad debts. Can you talk a little bit about what you're seeing there? I noticed that the -- sequentially, your provision was down, but it's not like the volume of admission-related uninsureds are down. So just any color there.

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Thank you, Frank. And Bill, you want to...
componenttext: All right. Thank you, Frank. And Bill, you want to...

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: As we look at [indiscernible] uninsured volumes, you could see it's 5.7% for the quarter, and on a year-to-date basis, it's fallen right in line with our expectations. When I look at uncompensated care, bad debt, charity and uninsured, combined, as I ment
componenttext: As we look at [indiscernible] uninsured volumes, you could see it's 5.7% for the quarter, and on a year-to-date basis, it's fallen right in line with our expectations. When I look at uncompensated care, bad debt, charity and uninsured, combined, as I mentioned in my comments and I look, really, the past 3 and even into Q3 of last year, it has remained very stable. When I look at our uncompensated care as a percentage of our adjusted revenue, it is relatively flat for the past 3 quarters. We anticipate our uninsured volume to track with our emergency room uninsured volume, and indeed, that's what exactly is happening. So I wouldn't really characterize the environment as very stable for us at this stage. Our teams are doing a great job as we continue to manage the collectibility and the revenue cycle associated with it. But on comp care, for the past 3 quarters has remained very stable.

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And now we'll go to Gary Lieberman with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And now we'll go to Gary Lieberman with Wells Fargo.

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: As we head into 2017, maybe discuss your expectations for exchange enrollment and any challenges that you might see from some managed care providers pulling back on the exchanges.
componenttext: As we head into 2017, maybe discuss your expectations for exchange enrollment and any challenges that you might see from some managed care providers pulling back on the exchanges.

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, Gary, thank you.
componenttext: All right, Gary, thank you.

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Gary, I'll try and others can add on. Obviously, I think it's still too early to predict what will happen in '17. We've always said that we think our exchange activity will track with enrollment. And so far, we haven't really seen material erosion fr
componenttext: Yes. Gary, I'll try and others can add on. Obviously, I think it's still too early to predict what will happen in '17. We've always said that we think our exchange activity will track with enrollment. And so far, we haven't really seen material erosion from payers leaving markets in that for next year. There's a bit of a handful, market-by-market, but it hadn't really kind of raised up as a material issue for us right now. So I really think we have to see what the enrollment trends are going to be and projected for '17 to kind of estimate whether [indiscernible] it is for us. I'm not so sure -- Sam, do you have any other planned comments that we've seen in the market on exchanges there. There's a handful here and there that are exiting and adding. So nothing material about this stage.

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, early stage is nothing material. I don't know exactly what the impact will be in 2017. However, we have added some payers here and there, and we will lose some payers as they exit. And I'm hopeful that our network is broad enough in order for us to
componenttext: Well, early stage is nothing material. I don't know exactly what the impact will be in 2017. However, we have added some payers here and there, and we will lose some payers as they exit. And I'm hopeful that our network is broad enough in order for us to absorb those, and we can maintain our market share, hopefully, even reposition our market share, in some cases. We'll just have to wait and see exactly how the exchange law shake out.

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Josh Raskin with Barclays.
componenttext: Next question comes from Josh Raskin with Barclays.

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question around the outpatient surgery volumes. Actually, it came a little bit below inpatient this quarter. I think I heard it was ASC, then the outpatient department. But any -- curious, and maybe more specifically on the surgery centers or, what you
componenttext: A question around the outpatient surgery volumes. Actually, it came a little bit below inpatient this quarter. I think I heard it was ASC, then the outpatient department. But any -- curious, and maybe more specifically on the surgery centers or, what you guys are seeing in terms of volumes and any initiatives or anything specific in any of your markets that's causing that change in trend.

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it actually is more on our historical trend. The first quarter was uniquely high. We couldn't put our fingers around exactly why it was as high as it was. But the second quarter was more on our historical trend, and it was very balanced between our
componenttext: Well, it actually is more on our historical trend. The first quarter was uniquely high. We couldn't put our fingers around exactly why it was as high as it was. But the second quarter was more on our historical trend, and it was very balanced between our hospital-based unit and our freestanding ambulatory surgery centers. Our growth is fairly broad-based across the different service lines in those centers and in our hospitals. We have a number of initiatives. Our OR choice initiative continues to yield value for it. And it's a satisfier for our physicians, and it's helping our patient flow, patient satisfaction. Secondly, we are in an acquisition mode on ambulatory surgery centers and endoscopic centers and have added, over the course of the last 12 to 18 months, quite a few additional units. And when you look at our composite non-same-store's ambulatory surgery center growth in the second quarter, I want to say it's about 4.5%, which reflects some of the acquisitions that we've done. And we believe them to be very strategic to position alignment, greater outreach into commercial segments and just advancing our larger network of offerings across HCA's markets. So we're very pleased with the result in the second quarter and believe we still have opportunities to grow our outpatient surgery volumes with our different initiatives.

componenttext: Well, I mean, all of our contract negotiations are a bit different, depending on the market, depending on their circumstance. But I mean, in general, there hasn't been any dramatic changes in our contract terms around pricing. And I think our reimbursement per unit is in line with our expectations this year, and we anticipate that being the case for next year as well. So I mean, there are pockets here and there. Anthem, I know, recently made an announcement about some challenges with their exchanges. We have a little bit of business with Anthem in the exchanges. We tended to deal with the local state Blues more than we do Anthem, given Texas, Florida, Tennessee, Kansas City, places like that, and so it's not really an Anthem issue for us as much as it is how the local Blue sort through their pricing challenges and medical off ratio issues and so forth. But in general, for HCA, there's not a lot of change.

componenttext: I just wanted to go to guidance. If we look at just the midpoint, it would call for around 5% EBITDA growth in the second half of the year versus the low 2s you've had in the first half. So I know comps do get easier, given some of the pressures in the third quarter. But can you talk about maybe other areas that give you comfort around that growth, just given the slowdown in the top line and maybe some of the continued cost pressures. Anything that considers seasonally, high-tech dollars, anything like that, that will give us or you increased comfort in sort of that 5% growth.

componenttext: [indiscernible] Bill surely have some comments. But yes, you're right. It implies a 5% growth to get to the midpoint as I think -- one of the major factors you touched on, the comps get easier, especially in the third quarter. Last year, we were a little bit soft, and so we should have a favorable comp for the third quarter. But when you look at our trends, we have factored all the current trends into our guidance and where we think we can achieve the outcome for the second half of the year. But I don't -- maybe a little bit of seasonality, typically, that we see in the latter half of the year, the fourth quarter especially. That's obviously a trend we see every year here over our net built into our thoughts. But nothing with high-tech or anything that would call out -- that would be outside of normal operations, would be contributing to that expectation for growth in the second half of the year.

componenttext: I don't really have a lot to add. As you said, third quarter, we -- I think we have a good comp on there. Fourth quarter, the last year was a big number for us. So as we revised our guidance, we think the midpoint range we're in is more reflective of where the current trends are, and we're comfortable with that.

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I will say that one thing, too, that, over comping, should help is on some of the contract labor issues that we dealt with in the second half of last year. As Sam described, although we still have opportunity to contract labor, it is moderating in terms o
componenttext: I will say that one thing, too, that, over comping, should help is on some of the contract labor issues that we dealt with in the second half of last year. As Sam described, although we still have opportunity to contract labor, it is moderating in terms of -- and stable in terms of where it is. So hopefully, we'll get a little bit of relief in the second half of the year relative to the comps on contract labor as well.

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to talk a little more about the supplied margins, and you guys called out you start about -- sorry, some weird feedback there. You've talked about continued supply chain initiatives, but supplies, as a percentage of revenue, has pretty much
componenttext: I just wanted to talk a little more about the supplied margins, and you guys called out you start about -- sorry, some weird feedback there. You've talked about continued supply chain initiatives, but supplies, as a percentage of revenue, has pretty much declined almost every year for almost a decade now. I mean, how much more options are there? Is this really just continuing to push through better pricing, given the GPO? Or are there other more strategic move that can continue to drive this measure down or, at least, that continue to slow the growth of supply versus everything else?

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, Andy. Thank you. Bill, you want to lay...
componenttext: All right, Andy. Thank you. Bill, you want to lay...

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me take the first shot. So as we look -- and as you note supply cost, as a percent of revenue year-over-year, we had 20 basis point decline. When I look at it here for the past 4 quarters, we're pretty consistent, 16.7% in Q2, 16.7% to Q1, 16.4% in Q4
componenttext: Let me take the first shot. So as we look -- and as you note supply cost, as a percent of revenue year-over-year, we had 20 basis point decline. When I look at it here for the past 4 quarters, we're pretty consistent, 16.7% in Q2, 16.7% to Q1, 16.4% in Q4, 16.7% in Q3. So it's very stable. And we do think that's an accomplishment, given the continued intensity increases in volume growth that we've seen over that time. Our supply chain team as well as our field operators have done an outstanding job from a variety of aspects around supply chain. First, relative to our GPO and contracting, we still have momentum in the marketplace with HealthTrust Purchasing Group, and they continue to have a lot of strong performance. And then our supply chain operations are really a key component of our supply chain story. We've spoken recently of one of our recent initiatives around pharmacy consolidation, where we can help control the pharmacy stand in utilization of inventory. That is paying great dividends as that initiative is rolling through the marketplace. So we've also got initiatives in the operating suites as well as other initiatives around our performance improvement activities. So when you couple supply chain initiatives operationally with the contracting statuses we have going on, I think that's all leading to us being able to at least maintain our margins on a supply cost line and remain with stability. You do recall, last year, we did speak in the third quarter of some pharmacy cost elevation with our pharmacy cost for adjusted admission or adjusted patient day was elevated in the second and third quarter of last year, mainly due to some high-cost drugs that obviously had a lot of press around that. We've seen those supply cost trends moderate over the -- or the pharmacy cost trends moderate over the past couple of quarters in response to some of just the public pressure on those high-cost drugs. So that is also benefiting our year-over-year kind of comparison.

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Bill, let me add -- this is Sam. Let me add one comment to that. I think it's another area of opportunity for HCA. And our clinical data warehouse and a number of our quality initiatives have sort of supply cost utilization, drug utilization, best pra
componenttext: And Bill, let me add -- this is Sam. Let me add one comment to that. I think it's another area of opportunity for HCA. And our clinical data warehouse and a number of our quality initiatives have sort of supply cost utilization, drug utilization, best practice identification and so forth attached to it. And as we engaged our physicians more than we've done in the past, they're understanding of how it helps them, how it helps their facility, how it helps their patients is another opportunity to -- I think we're in the early stages of execution on our supply costs. So marry it up with what Bill just talked about on contracting. Its supply chain operational management, coupled with data and insights connected to our physicians, is a very powerful combination that we think still has headroom.

componenttext: Yes. I'll take down, Gary. No policy changes relative to our recognition. In any period, they're sometimes subject to moves between uninsured discounts, charity and bad debt. componenttext: Okay then. A real question. headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think on the CJR is it varies by market a bit. We are trying to work with our physicians to identify the best course of action for our patients, whether that's the type of post-acute, how we interact with them post discharge from the hospital and
componenttext: Well, I think on the CJR is it varies by market a bit. We are trying to work with our physicians to identify the best course of action for our patients, whether that's the type of post-acute, how we interact with them post discharge from the hospital and so forth, and it's very, very early in understanding how impactful those are. As we transition -- I mean, we just got the regs on the cardiac thing. I mean, it's 700-plus pages of regs, I think. We haven't had a chance to study that yet. I think the one nuance for us was cardiology versus the orthopedic joints is we employ a large number of cardiologists across HCA, and our ability to integrate with them may be a bit easier than it is in some respects with orthopedics, which we don't employ as much. So we'll just have to wait and see how that plays out. That's still a proposed rule. We don't know if, in fact, it will go into effect and what the final rules will be on the cardiac side. But we're prepared. We've invested in infrastructure, corporate office and in our divisions. We've educated. We've -- we put policies and procedures in place on the CJR, and we'll, hopefully, see where it goes over the next 12 to 18 months.

componenttext: I had a question on the managed care and, just generally, the industry trends around moving to lower cost types of service. So when you had -- I don't know, it was like 1.5 percentage [indiscernible] the accretion was somewhere in the same range. Can you give us the color on the breakdown between the freestanding centers versus the outpatient departments and what the price differential is? And how that -- how much of a volume increase do you need to overcome the price essentially? And is that also in addition to the mixed shift the government putting pressure on your pricing?

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm not prepared to give pricing between the 2 units. I mean, the ASCs are a bit less priced, lower-priced in our hospitals, and that's because of some of the infrastructure requirements that it takes to operate a hospital-based unit. Capital require
componenttext: Yes, I'm not prepared to give pricing between the 2 units. I mean, the ASCs are a bit less priced, lower-priced in our hospitals, and that's because of some of the infrastructure requirements that it takes to operate a hospital-based unit. Capital requirements are different and so forth. Both components have about 50% to 55% of their volume being commercial patients. So outpatient business is predominantly a commercial book of business. A number of our surgery centers have broader clinical capabilities and can provide the type of care that our hospital-based units, but others can't. They don't have the nursing. They don't have the backup. The physicians aren't comfortable operating on certain type of patients and so forth. So there's all these nuances that go into it. Ambulatory surgery centers have been in our markets for a decade, and this dynamic has always existed. And so we've got the right balanced approach, we believe, inside of HCA to be able to respond to physician needs, patient needs, payer needs with our network, and we continue to add to both.

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: You've been focused on growing the ASC footprint and today spoke about the commitment to investing in outpatient. So if we take a step back and look at where you're putting capital to work, how do you see the acuity mix or a mix of inpatient to outpatient
componenttext: You've been focused on growing the ASC footprint and today spoke about the commitment to investing in outpatient. So if we take a step back and look at where you're putting capital to work, how do you see the acuity mix or a mix of inpatient to outpatient changing for HCA over the next 5 to 10 years?

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll say this. Fundamentally, the company has a strategy to enhance the clinical complexion of our facilities, and by that, I mean advance into deeper capabilities. In many markets, we are adding service lines, I'll call it, horizontally. We're brin
componenttext: Well, I'll say this. Fundamentally, the company has a strategy to enhance the clinical complexion of our facilities, and by that, I mean advance into deeper capabilities. In many markets, we are adding service lines, I'll call it, horizontally. We're bringing on new capabilities in cardiovascular care, oncology, pediatrics, whatever. And then vertically, we're deepening those capabilities inside of existing service lines, all intended on being able to keep a patient somewhere in the HCA system if they need deeper care and more complex care. So we support that out of our Clinical Services Group and out of our service line group up here in Nashville, where we can bring technology, we can bring best practices, we can bring a specialized talent to support that. So when I view the company's inpatient business, I anticipate it getting more acute and more complex over time. On the outpatient side, the company has had a very aggressive investment strategy over the last number of years. I think, Bill, our outpatient revenue is pushing 40% of our total. And so we balance out the $2.7 billion between inpatient capacity, outpatient, surgical capacity, imaging capacity, clinical capacity for urgent care and then also for emergency room, which is a big piece of our outpatient strategy as well. So all of those pieces and parts are connected to, really, a balanced approach to building out our networks and being attractive to our patients and our physicians.

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, Sheryl, you took on the subject that -- I think it's very important, the health care, over the next 5 to 10 years and thereafter. And we're investing and we have invested heavily on this because we see it, as I'll call it, a game changer for h
componenttext: Sure. Well, Sheryl, you took on the subject that -- I think it's very important, the health care, over the next 5 to 10 years and thereafter. And we're investing and we have invested heavily on this because we see it, as I'll call it, a game changer for health care. This is an area where I want to see HCA's lead, and I'm very excited about the early returns on what we're seeing. Again, we've invested in the clinical data warehouse. You think about what's happened over the last several years with electronic health record and investments that HCA and other providers have made and moving now to a digital medical record, because that was step one. Now we have all this clinical information on this digital format, what do we do with it? And there's a lot we can do with it. I'm going to ask that Dr. Perlin to touch on a couple. But some things that we're doing around substance care and, really, drop in mortality rates in our hospitals shown substances is -- in saving lives, is really happening every -- it's happening today in our facilities. And so there's examples of like that. So it's -- again, we're investing in -- not only in terms of the technical side of that, but we're investing in the human resource side of that with hiring very talented data scientists to help us take advantage of this. And then you think you move on from the structured data that we have to the unstructured data, and that's the length of processing, and where we can move the needle there is, again, something for the future that I'm very excited about. So Dr. Perlin's here. Jon, why don't you go a little more detail on that area?

headline: HCA Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks, Milton. In essence, really, we're at the point where we can begin to realize what we consider the digital dividend, how meaningful it is. I mean, as [indiscernible] say, it's always been very operations constraint-driven, and it's management
componenttext: Well, thanks, Milton. In essence, really, we're at the point where we can begin to realize what we consider the digital dividend, how meaningful it is. I mean, as [indiscernible] say, it's always been very operations constraint-driven, and it's management business decisions. Every aspect of our clinical care can be captured, and we can understand that to drive better clinical and operational business decisions. As Milton mentioned, it's really the gateway to improving the care for patients in real time in terms of substance, the ability to protect and even predict substance, #11 caused of death in the country ,#9 hospitals, #3 in all ICUs and really allows us to do what Milton says, save lives. In that process, it also allows us to drive our processes more efficiently, especially in terms of labor, especially in terms of the resources used to provide care, the supplies. In [indiscernible] MDs and care kings would be bold and answer questions and drive our clinical integration forward in a science-driven fashion, as similar to [indiscernible], which is really a requisite for maximizing margin. Now the current reimbursement don't -- really, it's the predicate for success in bundles in the future. It's finally the doorway to really personalize [indiscernible] in precision medicine. So it's really our mechanism to channel back the inevitable data stream that results from what we do, provide health care, and use it to drive better clinical business to operations decisions.
